Description: back pay award in unfair labor practices case
Info Source: Extracted from an NLRB dataset covering 1999-2011 downloaded at https://catalog.data.gov/dataset/nlrb-cats-final-c-case-data-bulk-19990101-20110930-in-xml

Company: McAllen Hospitals L.P., d/b/a/ South Texas Health System
Description: A hospital group based in McAllen, Texas, agreed to pay the United States $27.5 million to settle claims that it violated the False Claims Act, the Anti-Kickback Statute and the Stark Statute between 1999 and 2006 by paying illegal compensation to doctors in order to induce them to refer patients to hospitals within the group.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/texas-hospital-group-pays-us-275-million-settle-false-claims-act-allegations

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 6232: Residential Mental Retardation, Mental Health and Substance Abuse Facilities
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Universal Health Services Inc. and two subsidiaries reached a settlement in a False Claims Act lawsuit with the United States and the Commonwealth of Virginia under which UHS and its subsidiaries, Keystone Education and Youth Services LLC and Keystone Marion LLC, which did business as the Keystone Marion Youth Center, a residential facility in Marion, Va., agreed to pay $6.85 million to the United States and the commonwealth to settle allegations that they provided substandard psychiatric counseling and treatment to adolescents in violation of Medicaid requirements, falsified records and submitted false claims to the Medicaid program. By the time of the settlement UHS had closed the Marion facility.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/residential-youth-treatment-facility-medicaid-recipients-marion-virginia-agrees-resolve-false

Description: The Department of Justice reached 70 settlements involving 457 hospitals in 43 states for more than $250 million related to cardiac devices that were implanted in Medicare patients in violation of Medicare coverage requirements.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/nearly-500-hospitals-pay-united-states-more-250-million-resolve-false-claims-act-allegations

Court: Superior Court of State of California, County of Los Angeles
Private Litigation Case Title: BARBARA LASKO HOELLINGER ET AL VS UHS OF DELAWARE INC ET AL
Info Source: https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/352915/000119312507240306/d10q.htm#tx47682_10
Notes: In an SEC filing the company said it paid $10.4 million to settlement this and a related case but did not identify that other case.

Description: Universal Health Services paid the state $3.3 million to the state to settle allegation it provided sub-standard psychiatric care to adolescents in violation of federal and state Medicaid requirements, falsified records to cover up their serious violations and filed false Medicaid claims. This was part of a larger $6.85 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/va-universal-health-services-inc
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20140110201707/http://www.oag.state.va.us/Media%20and%20News%20Releases/News_Releases/Cuccinelli/102312_UHS.html

Company: UHS-CORONA, INC. D/B/A CORONA REGIONAL MEDICAL CENTER
Info Source: Extracted from a spreadsheet obtained from the NLRB through a Freedom of Information Act request fulfilled on 5/28/2020.

Description: Universal Health Services, Inc., UHS of Delaware, Inc., and Turning Point Care Center, LLC, a UHS facility located in Moultrie, Georgia, agreed to pay a combined total of $122 million to resolve alleged violations of the False Claims Act for billing for medically unnecessary inpatient behavioral health services, failing to provide adequate and appropriate services, and paying illegal inducements to federal healthcare beneficiaries.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/universal-health-services-inc-and-related-entities-pay-122-million-settle-false-claims-act

Company: UHS, Inc. and  UHS of Delaware, Inc, and HRI Clinics, Inc.
Description: UHS and subsidiaries agreed to pay $10 million in settlement of allegations the companies caused false claims to be made for unsuitable Medicaid services provided at psychiatric and behavioral health facilities. This settlement was for two cases separate from a multistate and federal case.
Info Source: https://www.mass.gov/news/universal-health-services-to-pay-massachusetts-more-than-15-million-to-resolve-whistleblower

Company: UHS, Inc and UHS of Delaware, Inc.
Description: UHS agreed to pay $117 million to settle multistate allegations the companies caused false claims to be made for unsuitable Medicaid services provided at psychiatric and behavioral health facilities. The settlement also involved the U.S. Justice Department, which issued its own announcement (see separate entry).
Info Source: https://ncdoj.gov/attorney-general-josh-stein-reaches-117-million-settlement-with-universal-health-services/
